Idiom (Tok Pisin): Sapos pikinini i no krai, mama i no save givim susu
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: If you don’t speak up, you won’t get what you need.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You must ask for help to receive it.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from maternal customs in PNG communities emphasizing vocal self-advocacy.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tok Pisin): /ˈsapɔs pikinini i no ˈkɾai, ˈmama i no ˈsave ˈɡivim ˈsusu/
First Example Sentence: Em i olsem long wok tu — sapos pikinini i no krai, mama i no save givim susu.
Second Example Sentence: Olgeta taim yu no tokaut, bai nogat man i helpim yu — olsem pikinini i no krai.
Third Example Sentence: Mi save tokim ol yangpela olsem: ‘Sapos yu laik samting, mas krai!’

Idiom (Tok Pisin): Wara i go antap long maunten
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Something impossible or highly unlikely has happened.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common PNG idiom derived from the natural flow of rivers always going downwards.
First Example Sentence: Em tok olsem em bai kisim promosen — wara i go antap long maunten!
Second Example Sentence: Tasol em tru? Wara i no save go antap long maunten!
Third Example Sentence: Em i mekim promis, tasol mipela save, wara i go antap long maunten tasol.

Idiom (Tok Pisin): Tingting i stap long antap long diwai
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone is daydreaming or thinking too much.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: They are distracted or lost in thought.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common across coastal PNG regions; compares thought to a bird high in a tree.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tok Pisin): /ˈtiŋtiŋ i stap loŋ anˈtap loŋ ˈdiwai/
First Example Sentence: Yu harim mi o nogat? Tingting bilong yu i stap long antap long diwai!
Second Example Sentence: Em i stap long klas tasol ai bilong em i stap long antap long diwai.
Third Example Sentence: Mi lukim em i no harim tok — tingting bilong em i stap long antap long diwai tru.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To talk without taking real action.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: They only talk but do nothing.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from PNG social critique about leadership and accountability.
First Example Sentence: Ol man i save kaikai long maus tasol taim wok i kamap.
Second Example Sentence: Em i save tok planti tasol — kaikai long maus tasol.
Third Example Sentence: Mipela no laik man i kaikai long maus tasol long dispela projek.

Idiom (Tok Pisin): Paitim han long ai bilong san
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To do something hopelessly or in vain.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To waste effort on something impossible.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: A poetic image used in literature and oratory, symbolic of futile struggle.
First Example Sentence: Taim yu laik senisim tingting bilong em, em olsem paitim han long ai bilong san.
Second Example Sentence: Mi bin traim, tasol mi painimaut em i olsem paitim han long ai bilong san.
Third Example Sentence: Yu no inap kisim tru — em olsem paitim han long ai bilong san.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from oratory culture; compares empty talk to wind.
First Example Sentence: Em i save mekim tok bilong win long olgeta miting.
Second Example Sentence: Tok bilong win i no inap stretim problem.
Third Example Sentence: Planti taim ol lida i save mekim tok bilong win tasol.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To face difficulties or become overwhelmed.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common in coastal PNG regions; ‘wara’ symbolizes emotion or chaos.
First Example Sentence: Taim em lusim wok, em bungim het wantaim wara tru.
Second Example Sentence: Mi no save bai mi mekim wanem — mi bungim het wantaim wara nau.
Third Example Sentence: Ol famili bilong em tu bungim het wantaim wara long dispela samting.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To stop talking about something taboo or sensitive.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Linked to traditional respect codes forbidding discussion of certain matters.
First Example Sentence: Ol i tokim mi long rausim maus long dispela toktok.
Second Example Sentence: Em i samting bilong ol bikpela — rausim maus tasol.
Third Example Sentence: Mipela mas rausim maus long dispela samting long nau.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To feel emotional pain or burden.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common across PNG cultures referring to emotional weight felt in the body.
First Example Sentence: Mi save karim hevi long bel taim mi tingim em.
Second Example Sentence: Em i stap isi tasol, tasol mi save em i karim hevi long bel.
Third Example Sentence: Mipela olgeta i karim hevi long bel long dispela taim nogut.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To enter a dangerous or risky situation.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from the danger of stepping into fire; widespread PNG idiom.
First Example Sentence: Yu laik go mekim toktok wantaim ol — yu putim lek long paia nau.
Second Example Sentence: Em i save, tasol em putim lek long paia nating.
Third Example Sentence: Mipela tokim em long no go — em putim lek long paia yet.
